content:
If anybody can make the border around topic box darker it would be great!
here it is now:
image.png

But it should be something like this:

.dark-theme:root #compose-content, .dark-theme:root .draft-row .draft-info-box, .dark-theme:root .message_list .recipient_row, .dark-theme:root .message_row, .dark-theme:root .preview_message_area {
    border-color: hsla(0,0%,0%,.6);
}

so it would match the border on the recipient bar:
image.png
The recepient bar border should be the same... and I suggest 60% transparent black.

The strange thing that I don't understand is that a border color of the bottom of the topic box is cut somehow by something which isn't black or 60% black:
image.png
by "topic box" do you mean "preview_message_area"?
I mean the whole rectangle which includes the recipient bar and all the messages

Ah, so a single block of recipient bar and messages in the message view? It's helpful when you're more specific, because topic box can also refer to part of the compose box, and your screenshot didn't show much context for where you were talking about.
I guess it is .message_list .recipient_row .message_row:last-of-type .messagebox
I mean this rectangle
image.png
I'm wondering if these should be part of the background changes or a more general collection of color tweaks. [edit: moved the messages]
for some reason the last message sets this bottom-border
It's possible the border issues are more related to @Aman (amanagr)'s work, so tagging him in case that's true.

border-color: hsla(0,0%,0%,.6);

Having a border-color with opacity is not a good idea since they will break if the background color changes.
If we want a different border color to go with the new background, it should be part of the background color change PR.

@Vlad Korobov I'm finding this thread a bit confusing to follow. Can you list what borders you'd like to change, with either the specific classname or a picture of the element you're talking about, and also share a color that doesn't have opacity?

Having a border-color with opacity is not a good idea since they will break if the background color changes

I don't understand that. I think opacity helps to match the background. And in the case when border doesn't have any hue it is a universal method.
Border could be internal (shadow) and external (shadow or css border) and in all the cases transparency is a good tool to use
